content.description: Fun climb up a big sweep of rock.  I'm always impressed at the varied nature of 5.8s and this one is no exception. The first pitch is the exciting part, set your anchors as high as you'd like after the steep stuff, ~90'. P2, a comfortable hand/fist off-angle pitch that ran an entire 70m all the way to where the crack peters out near the top.  I then wandered around unroped to find the beige rap anchors (up right) for 3 raps down off double ring anchors that lands about 70 feet right of the start.  A little more adventurous than the regular clip-ups.
content.protection: I carried a std rack of nuts, double 1-3 cams and some long runners. Maybe an optional #4 if you want for the belay.
content.location: This is currently the left most route on the face.  The vague path up from the valley floor comes up under some eyebrow roofs on the left with an inset face with white streaks.  You'll see a somewhat intimidating roof system that comes over from the right and features a left facing corner perhaps 35' up.  Just below that there are some big flat rocks and a small right facing flake/dihedral.  You go up the face and cross onto the flake, moving left up a small ramp up to the roof, undercling out to the corner and up (fight the bush).  Step back right to the long crack above and set up a belay.  I passed 2 fixed nuts.

content.description: Start by climbing 30 feet of easy 5.9 bolted wide buggy crack to gain an interesting footwork dependent crux to transition to the left arete. Airy and delicate moves deliver you to the slopey topout exit moves and the chains. There was/is a huge Raven's nest in the roof just left of this line visible by peering around left from the anchors.
content.location: This climb is in the East facing alcove just East of the Pandemic wall and before the project wall. A striking feature that will be obvious when you see it.

content.description: Get on and ride - it’s guaranteed to please! Short but stout climbing through two roof systems. Mount up on the big undercling on the left side of the roof systems to the left of Pandemic above the east slab routes. Pull over onto the slab where the holds suddenly thin out and pad your way up to the base of the 2nd roof. Engaging and powerful climbing leads to an interesting roof mount terminating in a unique chickenhead jug and pull-over onto the slab above.
content.location: This climb is the left-most route on the Pandemic wall. It starts far left on a ledge that is pretty much even with the bolts of the easy 5th class short bolted slabs.

content.description: Very Cool line. Start from a stepped-up bloc with your belayer below. Climb right-facing sidepulls through a series of cruxey liebacks to gain a decent rest. Cool underclings and big pulls guard easier runout climbing above. Shares anchors with The Puzzler.
content.location: On the "Project Wall" between The Baja Golden Panel to the immediate East and "Ambient Daydream" to the West and slightly downhill.

content.description: This long route will deposit you on top of the Toaster formation but needs a bit of work. The current anchors only allow a lead with an 80 meter rope or with a lot of shenanigans, experience and a 70 meter. It would do well with a midway anchor if anyone is so inclined. Basically two very cool 5.11c's stacked into one mega pitch. fun!
content.location: Just left of Pandemic and two left of Lippy Dyke.

content.description: This may be the best 12d in the Laramie River Range. Maybe Wyoming. A short 5.11 intro gains a face-arete bouldery v6 crux. Then share the no-hands from "GTC". Then embark on wild roof climbing to an amazing juggy quartz dyke! This last roof is 12a-c depending on height, but not a game-changer. Finish up amazing outro moves on perfect rock. Get on up!
content.location: This route is immediately right of "Gleaming The Cube" ("GTC") on the nosey pillar on the right side of the Pandemic wall.

Just left and down hill of the Golden Face Panel with "Baja Koolaid". This is the left line that starts from talus jumble and tackles a short roof boulder with an amazing basketball sloper starting hold under the roof. Fire straight up on abstruse sequences that defy easy deciphering and then remember all of the subtle intricacies and string together a completely awesome chain of moves. Battle you will.

content.description: This is the wonderful swirly stone route just left of Lippy Dyke that was begging to be bolted and climbed. Start down and right of the first bolt on a big jug rail and work up and left, past two bolts to a recondite crux and keep traversing left on sublime climbing; mostly tech slopers and pinches. hanging the draws is a bit scary from left of the bolts, and is much easier if you climb above the bolts a tad. spooky falls, although unlikely, would result in a bit of a pendjy. There has been some discussion about relocating bolts 4 to the top 8"-12" to the left for easier, less scary position and clipping. The FA'ist is fine with this. Sustained and technical, this route is AMAZING! Can set up a TR or hang bolts from "Social Distancing".
content.location: 10 feet left of Lippy Dyke.

content.description:
Another nicely bolted moderate slab in the sun.  Collect the whole set!

The book calls it 5.7, and it is harder (IMHO) than Al.  What do you think?
content.protection: 6 or 7 bolts to the ring anchors.
content.location: This is the line of bolts just right of the obvious crystal staircase (Al Roker's Dead).

climbs.name: Lippy Dyke 5.11a
climbs.fa: Dennis Horning, Rachel Lynn & Zach Orenczak 2005

content.description: This stiff little number climbs a prominent dark water streak.  Steep, pumpy climbing with a final crux below the anchors.  Listed as 5.9+ in Zack's guidebook...take that with a large grain of salt.
content.location: Starts at the obvious dark streak of rock 15 feet left of the arete route Gleaming the Cube.  The belay stance is not exactly flat, and the beginning moves are tricky so attentive belaying is a must.

content.description: Fantastic warm-up to the left of the Project wall, climb a cool easy boulder problem to a slab and alpine feeling buggy corner. Exit a bulgy flared crack up high to gain the anchors. The left stat var. of this is "Ambient Daydream" and connects into this line after a couple bolts and a harder intro boulder.
content.location: Just near the massive pine tree. A great central hang.

content.description: Start up the lower arete with a nice crack for the left hand. Move up and out right under the roof with difficult climbing. Follow the bolts up and a bit right to a grovel top out.
content.location: First bolted route right of Lippy Dyke.

content.description: This stellar addition is immediately left of "Gleaming the Cube". Tackle broken high-quality rock up easy 5.10 to a roof and tackle a hard boulder problem to mount a simple perch and clip the anchors. Subtract or add a star and give yourself 12a-12c for using the left wall or the chimney. The route is still enjoyable to climb this way, but is a completely different experience. Definitely an unusual but thoroughly enjoyable climb.
content.location: On the overhanging feature just right of "Lippy Dyke".

content.description: Engaging juggy climbing in the crack system down low leads to a long move out to a shelf on the face and then another long move to the resting jug. Get it back here for a final challenge up the block and an exciting pull-over onto the slab above.
content.location: Just right of "Baja Koolaid" on the Golden Panel on the East end of the Toaster formation.

content.description: Start up a mini-triangular slab just right of Frankenpoodle and lift-the-car-off-the-baby with a burly V7 intro boulder to great jugs. Then climb 5.11 until able to stem to the top of the Frankenpood for a great and exposed rest. From here there is a 5.11 runout (a bolt hole is drilled and a bolt needs to be added). Then encounter another burly crux before sweet finger locks and a cool top out onto the lunch ledge. Sit down, take your shoes off and enjoy the view for however long before tackling the final 12a headwall. Super fun climbing the whole way! You will feel like you are "currently dreaming" your way up this immaculate climb.
content.protection: 15 QD! Seriously! (one bolt missing has created a safe run-out in the middle. FA done w/o this bolt. We will add a bolt and remove this comment)
content.location: This epic line is on the overhanging crescent feature just left of the Golden Face Panel feature of the Toaster Wall formation.

content.description: Bouldery start leads to a couple balancy sections separated by good rests. Meander up abstruse sequences to earn the pumpy technical crux at the last bolt to the anchors. Dig deep on decent crimps with meh feet to clip the chains or take the big, safe ride! Must do for the astute puzzle lover.
content.location: Just left of Bon Bini, which has an obvious question mark feature and appears a bit easier right off the ground. Just right of the dihedral.

climbs.name: Bon Bini
climbs.fa: Rachael Lynn and Zach Orenczak, Spring 2005

content.description: This route is just right of center on the clean vertical face on the right side of Toaster Wall.  It ascends a blocky ledge system down low and then follows edges and seams up the vertical face to the anchors.  A defined crux comes between bolts 4 and 5 as you conquer the bulge.

This fun link up creates the likely highest quality line on the Golden Panel: Start up Baja Koolaid and do that crux, move left past the obvious link-up-bolt (drilled but not added yet) into the top of the super difficult Blade Runner climb avoiding its V9 crux. Go to the top in the usual fashion. May be 12c, will adjust grade(s) based on community consensus.
content.location: Just left of Frankenpoodle, start up the right side of the ramp to a ledge at 8 feet and head up through the opening crux of Baja Koolaid. Hang the draw out left after you have made the big move to the perfect flat crimp up and right on that climb. The second half is amazing 5.11 slab.

content.description: Short bouldery crux off a ledge leads to fun easy 5.11 face climbing.
content.location: Right of Bon Bini.

climbs.name: Ambien Daydream
climbs.fa: Rachel Lynn, Zach Orenczak & Kyle Chitty

content.description: This is the left start variation of the route Intolerant of the Intolerant (5.10b).  Climb up and right along the left side of a thin black section of rock for 2 bolts to join the other route.  Move up through easy rock to the bottom of a left facing corner. Layback through a brief but strenuous section followed by another short crack before the anchors.
content.location: Approximately 30 feet right of Phil's Folly, near a very large pine tree, start up the twin black water streaks the merge into one.

content.description: The Laramie Range book calls this the New World Order Wall. Lots of moderate sport routes here, wish I'd done more. True to the name, it gets toasty in the sun.  The book calls this 5.7, but it's easier than the climb to the right.  See what you think.
content.location: Continue up right on the talus under the wall until you come to a good sized slab with lots of obvious bolt lines.  Al is the first one and goes up a quartz staircase to a slab finish and ring anchors.

content.description: This is the amazing line just right of "Bon Bini" that tackles a super tough v10 facey boulder followed by immaculate easy 5.12 face and then a slab outro that will blow your mind. Original and challenging, this line is a stunner and the current hardest addition to the LRR.
content.location: Easy climbing to a ledge and then nails hard face crimping to an unlikely dead point. Bring fingers of steel.

content.description: Fun slabs right of Three Amigos and left of the giant tree.
Just right of the 5.9
Fun technical warm up. hard for 5.7. Especially for gym climbers.

pathTokens: Laramie Peak Wildlife Habitat Management Area
